Comment: Here is an interesting miniature I played on the ICC.  Time control G-5.
My standard response to the queen pawn openings.  I have played the Nimzo-Bogo systems for the past 5 years and find they are very solid and can provide interesting kingside attacking chances.
Heading straight for the main lines, many players who want to avoid theory will try the Tromp, the Torre, the London, or even 2. Nc3 aiming for a Veresov or a gambit with 3. e4!?.
Implementing the light-squared strategy in the center and preparing to develop the bishop to b4.
Supporting the e4-push which forces black to respond in the center immediately with, ...d5, ...c5, or my favorite...
Bb4.  Heading straight for the Nimzo-Indian where black counts on his pieces to control the center and also on rapid development.
The classical variation of the Nimzo.  There are nine different strategies that white can adopt against the Nimzo and my opponent chooses the most popular.

It's no secret that my pet line against the classical is a little known variation known as the Zurich.  Rapid development coupled with an immediate threat to the d-pawn which white has temporarily abandoned.
Probably the most sound reply.  White keeps up his development and keeps the c1-h6 diagonal for his dark-squared bishop.
With this move it's clear that black wants to swap the dark-squared bishop for the knight and try to arrange an ...e5 break to free the other bishop and gain some space in the center.
Immediately forcing the swap.
Avoiding any pawn weaknesses, but temporarily leaving e4 in black's control.
Avoiding any pawn weaknesses, but temporarily leaving e4 in black's control.

This is the move I forgot when I played this line agains GM Varushan Akobian in a Seattle Simul.  In that game I played the immediate ...Ne4 and ...f5 and Var eventually took over the center and won around move 42.
A solid an aggressive continuation.  I decide to hit the bishop.
Not quite the best move as this helps black develop and brings the queen into position to assist in an ...e5 break.
Not quite the best move as this helps black develop and brings the queen into position to assist in an ...e5 break.
This is also a bit odd as e3 is the theoretical recommendation, bringing the other bishop into play and preparing to castle.
This is also a bit odd as e3 is the theoretical recommendation, bringing the other bishop into play and preparing to castle.
Simple development.  0-0 is also fine.
Keeping control of the d4-square.  11. e4 would allow black easy equality after 11...e5; 12. d5 Nd4.
Castling before the central break ...e5.
Be2 is better as there really isnt a target on the kingside after ...h6.  White will also many times play e4 to stop ...f5, when the bishop on d3 is poor.
